text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text occupying lower two-thirds of the page, surmounted by a full-width horizontal register of four contiguous narrative scenes; text and image separated and unified by a red frame line; wide blank margins around both elements.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata book hand with red rubricated initials, professional execution with regular abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for haloes and divine figures; blue background establishes heavenly context and alternates with green garments; layered application with white highlights on folds; red used in framing and initials for hierarchical emphasis; original pigments well-preserved with minimal oxidation

features: Horizontal register divided into four equal panels
Equal figure scale for narrative continuity

decorative_elements: Simple red frame surrounding image and text
Red rubric initial at text heading
Vertical white pilaster separators between panels

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine black ink outlines drawn with quill, varying line weight for contours and internal detail
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal tonal modeling using white highlights and slight pigment gradations, no extensive hatching
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat plane with no true vanishing point; figures overlap modestly but remain uniformly scaled

scene_relationships.subject: Two bishops in mitres conversing
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Introduces ecclesiastical authority leading to lay petitioners
visual_connections: Green and ochre robes echo later garments
Figures face right toward next panel

scene_relationships.subject: Two female supplicants in tunics
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: They approach the saint for healing
visual_connections: Violet tunic echoes bishop’s cloak hue
Halos appear on saint and bishops

scene_relationships.subject: Female saint with halo healing kneeling penitent
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to presentation of child before clerics
visual_connections: Saint’s ochre gown repeats earlier colour
Penitent’s blue garment links to background

scene_relationships.subject: Woman at doorway presenting a child to two bishops and female saint
visual_connections: Doorway arch continues architectural band motif
Halos on clerics and child maintain sanctity theme
Figures oriented toward center of panel

visual_continuity: Burnished gold haloes on all saints

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature comprises four contiguous scenes in a single horizontal register containing ten figures in total: Panels 1–4 depict respectively two haloed bishops in green and violet chasubles; two laywomen in ochre and grey tunics gesturing; a female saint in ochre gown blessing a kneeling penitent in blue; and a doorway scene where a veiled woman offers a swaddled child to two mitred bishops and the saint. All figures stand upon a continuous ground line against an ultramarine field. Bishops wear green mitres with gold trim, liturgical dalmatics and linen undergarments; one holds a closed book. Laywomen wear long tunics with minimal trim and loose veils. The saint’s drapery shows subtle white highlights. The kneeling penitent’s hands are clasped. The final scene’s doorway is rendered as a simple white arch. Spatially, figures overlap slightly but remain on a flat plane. Depth is implied by overlapping and the doorway’s recess. Costume materials include woollen cloth-of-­gold simulated by ochre pigment and linen veils with fine ink stroke hatching.

religious: two mitred bishops with gold haloes
female saint with halo blessing the sick

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum of uniform thickness, smooth flesh side preparation evident under close inspection; ruled with plummet lines; quire gathering typical of prayer book folios.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent pigment retention with vivid azurite and gold; minor flaking of white highlights; slight staining in lower margin; minimal parchment cockling.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso preparation beneath gold haloes

functional_analysis.intended_audience: individual patron for personal prayer (book of hours)

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This page illustrates a mid-14th-century vernacular devotional tradition likely produced in a northern French workshop. The narrative register presents a coherent hagiographic cycle of episcopal intercession and miraculous healing, underscored by the acquisition and presentation of a divine child. The Gothic textura quadrata script and precise rubrication indicate professional scribal involvement, while the fluid quill-drawn outlines and restrained palette demonstrate a single master illuminator’s hand. The predominance of azurite and gold leaf reflects both theological significance—blue for heavenly intercession, gold for sanctity—and the patron’s resources. The simple architectural separators, rather than elaborate gothic micro-architecture, suggest a workshop favoring clarity over opulence. Iconographically, the repeated depiction of haloes and episcopal insigne emphasizes hierarchical mediation between lay supplicants and the Virgin’s miracle-working power. The horizontal sequential format, rather than compartmentalizing into framed miniatures, allows continuous narrative flow, aligning with emerging tastes for legible, moralizing images in private prayer books. Comparative analysis with contemporary Hours of Jeanne d’Evreux reveals similar palette choices but a more austere framing and fewer foliated borders. This hybrid of traditional saint-life cycles with economical layout likely catered to a bourgeois patron seeking devotional efficacy paired with refined but measured luxury.
